item.title: BisBabble Interview - ShadowCrypto
item.description:
Welcome to another edition of BisBabble! In this episode, we chat with ShadowCrypto, a dedicated Bismuth supporter and key contributor to the Pawer bot.

The Interview

Q: Hello Shadow! We heard about you in a previous BisBabble episode. You are a vibrant supporter of Bismuth and a much-appreciated code contributor to the Pawer bot. Can you tell us a little about yourself?

A: I‚Äôm a programmer by profession and a photographer by passion, drawn to both shadows and crypto‚Äîhence my username (pun intended).

Q: Since forums don‚Äôt allow for direct observation, how do you describe yourself at dinner parties?

A: As an introvert, I prefer to stay silent and focus on the main purpose‚Äîeating, a lot!.

Q: Well, introvert maybe, but you were the one who brought @aravindballa to the party‚Äîthanks for that! How did you get into programming in the first place?

A: I have an interesting backstory for this.

  • When I finished school and had to choose a field of study, I told my cousin, ‚ÄúAnything except computers.‚Äù
  • A couple of years later, I ended up doing my undergraduate degree in Computer Science.

I never regretted it‚Äîevery day was fun!
I first encountered coding through coursework and was fascinated by how a few lines of code could perform complex tasks.
That simple realization keeps me motivated to this day.

Q: The preferred minimalism can be seen in your code. So, programming is your day job?

A: Yes, I pay my bills with programming.

Q: How did you get introduced to blockchain?

A: Like many others‚Äîthrough Bitcoin.

  • Initially, I was interested in crypto as an investment.
  • At first, Bitcoin‚Äôs technical details were overwhelming.
  • Over time, I took the time to understand it better.
  • I still don‚Äôt know everything in detail, but I now have a decent high-level understanding.

Q: What‚Äôs the piece of code you‚Äôre most proud of?

A:
Back when I was new to HTML & CSS, I worked on email templates.

  • I migrated existing templates to plain HTML & CSS/SASS.
  • Reduced 1700 lines of code to 450 per template.
  • Supported all browsers & mail clients.
  • There were 10 such templates in total!

It was a great learning and implementation experience.

Q: Minimalism again! What programming languages have you worked with?

  • Python & Java (mostly).
  • C/C++? Still unsure if I should count them‚ÄîI started with them but didn‚Äôt continue afterward.

Q: What led you to Bismuth?

A: @cryptotyrion introduced me to Bismuth.
The fact that it was written in Python (my favorite language) made me dig deeper.

Q: What‚Äôs your experience in the crypto field?

A: I‚Äôve been an investor/trader since 2017.

Q: What would you say is Bismuth‚Äôs biggest strength?

A: The devs.

I‚Äôm amazed at how hard and smart they work, even in the toughest times.
Also, the community is incredibly welcoming.

Bismuth was my first open-source contribution.
At first, I had many fears about where to start, but the devs made it easy and were super helpful.
It‚Äôs a perfect learning environment for blockchain development‚Äîespecially in Python.

Q: Thanks! We try to be welcoming because we need contributors like you‚Äîand you‚Äôve proved yourself! What would you say is Bismuth‚Äôs biggest weakness?

A: The business model.

I may be wrong or less informed, but I don‚Äôt fully understand how Bismuth generates money within its ecosystem.

Q: You‚Äôve mainly worked on the Pawer Discord bot. Are there other parts of Bismuth‚Äôs ecosystem you‚Äôd like to explore?

A: Absolutely!
I‚Äôd love to explore:

  • ZircoDice üé≤
  • Dragginator üêâ
  • Other DApps üöÄ

I also want to build my own DApp.
If anyone has ideas and needs a partner, hit me up!

Q: Most loved programming language & why?

A: Python‚Äîas simple as writing a few statements in English.

Q: Most hated programming language & why?

A: I haven‚Äôt figured that out yet.

Q: You‚Äôll live longer if you only love and don‚Äôt hate‚Äîgood call! On a more personal note, what are you up to when you‚Äôre not coding?

A: I‚Äôm a photographer at heart‚Äîthat‚Äôs what keeps me alive. üì∑

I love finding patterns, symmetry, and silhouettes in unexpected places.
Also, I won a national-level award and received a few other recognitions‚Äîmaking my parents proud at a young age.

Q: Do you see any connections between photography and coding?

A: Great question!

For me, programming is also an art form.

  • People express creativity in different ways‚Äîprogramming is one of them.
  • Photography and coding share similarities‚Äîcomposing a shot vs. composing a function,
    keeping things minimal, finding patterns, and reusing them.

Both give me the same dopamine hit‚Äîwhether I capture a great photo or write a beautiful script.

Q: Your best piece of programming advice?

üí° Programming is evolving fast‚Äîit takes just a few days to start learning a language (especially Python).
üí° You can automate daily tasks or build fun projects‚Äîjust for fun!
üí° Not everything you learn has to make money‚Äîenjoy programming!

Thanks a lot, ShadowCrypto, for answering our questions! May the good vibes stay with you! üöÄ

Meet ShadowCrypto

You can connect with ShadowCrypto on:

  • Bismuth Discord
  • Twitter: @_shadow_crypto

References

  • Discord
  • Twitter @_shadow_crypto

item.title: BisBabble Interview - Endogen
item.description:
In this second issue of the ‚ÄúBisBabble‚Äù series we welcome Endogen, a long-time Bismuth supporter and developer of the Bismuth Telegram Bot, Bauer.

üìù The Interview

Q: Can you tell us a little about yourself?

A: Sure! I‚Äôm a 38-year-old software engineer from Germany, but I‚Äôve only been in the software industry for about 8 years.
Before that, I worked as a retail salesman for an electronics retailer, but I didn‚Äôt enjoy it‚Äîso I decided to study Software Engineering üôÇ.

As a kid, I was naturally drawn to the internet and fascinated by software. Unlike everything else that seemed to decay over time, software stayed the same‚ÄîI found that really interesting.

Today, I work as a SAP consultant, helping companies implement SAP ME (Manufacturing Execution) to create paperless plants. Unfortunately, I no longer code at work, but I still love it and do it privately for fun.

Q: How do you describe yourself at dinner parties?

A: I don‚Äôt. I prefer to stay in the background and listen to people üòâ.

But if I had to, I‚Äôd say I‚Äôm drawn to things outside the mainstream. Life is too short to be bored by mediocre stuff.
For example, I‚Äôve always been fascinated by psychoactive drugs, consciousness, and philosophical theories.
However, after having two kids, responsibility took over‚Äîbut I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm still strange as hell üòÜ.

That‚Äôs what I‚Äôd say at a dinner party. And the one or two people still cool with me after that? Those are the ones I‚Äôd have a beer with.

Q: What made you want to start coding?

A: I love the idea of creating something from nothing. Software is especially interesting because of its unique properties‚Äîonce it exists, it can be used anywhere by anyone.

The fact that someone can write code, publish it on GitHub, and people worldwide can use it fascinates me.
I believe proprietary software will become niche in the future‚Äîso everything I code privately will always be open source.

Q: Is programming your day job or a hobby?

A: It was my day job for a short time, but now it‚Äôs just a hobby.
I‚Äôm not the best programmer, and I have other skills, but I love coding and do it in my free time.

Q: How did you get introduced to blockchain?

A: I first heard about Bitcoin while studying. I thought it was cool but didn‚Äôt look into it much.
Years later, when I saw that these coins actually had value, I started digging deeper.

I was fascinated by the decentralization, censorship resistance, and independence from traditional finance.
It was obvious‚Äîthis is the start of a new paradigm.

Q: What piece of code do you wish you had written?

A: TensorFlow üòÄ

Q: What code are you most proud of?

A: Honestly? The Bismuth Telegram Bot.
It may sound silly, but it‚Äôs the first project where I really liked how the code was structured.

And hey‚ÄîI even got paid for coding in my free time! YAY! üéâ

Q: What programming languages have you worked with?

A:

  • Java (for work) ‚Äì liked it at first.
  • Python (privately) ‚Äì loved it. Since then, I never touched any other language.
  • JavaScript & Vue ‚Äì played around briefly, but nothing serious.

Q: What led you to Bismuth?

A: I love the crypto industry‚Äîit‚Äôs hilariously scammy, overblown, and overvalued. But on a serious note, it‚Äôs the future.
No one can stop it‚Äîit will drag the world with it, no matter what anyone tries to do.

Since I‚Äôm also obsessed with Python, I looked for a Python-based blockchain.
I didn‚Äôt want just a Python client‚ÄîI wanted something I could tear apart and understand.

That‚Äôs how I found Bismuth. When I saw the logo and its connection to the chemical element, I was hooked.
I love fractals, and Bismuth reminds me of that.

Q: What‚Äôs your experience in the crypto field?

A:

  • First got into Bitcoin.
  • Then found Monero (XMR)‚Äîloved the idea, but disliked C++.
  • Got involved with Monero‚Äôs ecosystem (created a proposal for a Monero Marketplace Bot ‚Äì üîó Proposal).
  • With Bismuth, I could finally get into the code, which I loved.
  • I also enjoy trading‚Äînot good at it, but for me, it‚Äôs a game & hobby.

Q: What would you say is Bismuth‚Äôs biggest strength?

A: It‚Äôs coded in Python.
That fact alone attracts a lot of competent developers.
Combined with Bismuth‚Äôs features, it‚Äôs an exciting and fun project.

Q: What would you say is Bismuth‚Äôs biggest weakness?

A: The code itself.
The ideas behind Bismuth are brilliant, and HCLivess (Bismuth‚Äôs creator) is godlike.

However, the code structure needs improvement.

Q: Any thoughts on the current crypto industry?

A: The next big thing? Mining isn‚Äôt the way forward.

We need nodes that directly validate and store transactions, receiving fees without intermediaries.
If your blockchain requires a second layer, then your first layer isn‚Äôt the future.

Also‚ÄîGossip protocols, WTF.

Q: Most loved programming language, and why?

A: Python! Python! Python! üöÄ

Q: Most hated programming language, and why?

A: I can‚Äôt judge many languages, but between Python and Java‚ÄîI find Java boring.
After falling in love with Python, I never needed anything else.

Q: What are you up to when you‚Äôre not coding?

A:

  • Playing with my kids üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶
  • Thinking about obscure stuff ü§Ø
  • Gardening üå±
  • Hanging out with friends üçª
  • Downhill biking üö¥ (but no time for it anymore‚Äîkids come first!).

I don‚Äôt take life too seriously and avoid most social activities.

Q: Your best piece of programming advice?

A:
‚ùå Don‚Äôt read books about programming.
‚úÖ Just code.

üôè Thanks a lot, Endogen, for answering our questions! Keep up the great work! üöÄ

References

  • Github - Bismuth Telegram Bauer Bot

item.title: BisBabble Interview - Aravind
item.description:
Welcome to the BisBabble series! In this issue, we chat with Aravind, a recent contributor to the Bismuth project.
He shares insights into his background, interests, and development work.

üìù The Interview

Q: Can you tell us a little about yourself?

A: I make sure I taste all the varieties of food being served. üçΩÔ∏è

Q: Is programming your day job or a hobby?

A: It‚Äôs my day job‚ÄîI work as a JavaScript Developer.

Q: Code you‚Äôre most proud of?

A: My personal website (I guess).
There‚Äôs a module that dynamically generates social media preview images (Open Graph) when the site builds‚ÄîI really like that part.

Q: What programming languages have you worked with?

  • C ‚Äì Learned it, but never liked it.
  • Python ‚Äì Enjoyed using Django to build things.
  • Java ‚Äì My first paid job was in Java, but I wasn‚Äôt a fan‚Äîmaybe because of how I learned it in college.

Q: You give talks about cutting-edge tech (like Gatsby). Do you see that as part of your job?

A: I love sharing what I learn and helping others on their developer journey. That‚Äôs why I write a blog, too‚Äîit‚Äôs a pleasure!
Also, I feel noticed in the community when I talk about what I‚Äôve learned.
I believe everyone should share, because it‚Äôs beautiful to see different perspectives‚Äîsometimes they open new doors.

Q: What‚Äôs your experience in the crypto field?

A: I‚Äôd say I‚Äôm a beginner who understands what a blockchain is.

Q: How did you get introduced to blockchain?

A:

  • In college, I heard about a guy making money trading crypto.
  • I asked him what a blockchain was‚Äîhe couldn‚Äôt explain it properly.
  • That led me to do some research, but I was still confused.
  • A year ago, I met someone who runs a blockchain-based company.
  • Talking to him gave me clarity and motivated me to learn more.

Q: What led you to Bismuth specifically?

A: All because of Shadowcrypto.

Q: Has the perception of crypto changed for you since that college trader?

A: Absolutely‚Äîa lot has changed.
For me, crypto is already influencing the world, but it will take time for people around me to fully adopt it.
I‚Äôve even read that my state government is using blockchain (not exactly crypto) for certain projects, which is interesting!

Q: What do you like about Bismuth?

A: The community‚Äîyou all are so nice! ü§ó
Also, Bismuth is written in Python, the only language I understand apart from JavaScript.

Q: Most loved programming language & why?

A: JavaScript (of course).

It started as just a browser scripting language, but after the V8 engine, it became much more powerful.
Now, you can write it anywhere:

  • Webpages
  • Servers
  • Mobile (Ionic, React Native)
  • IoT devices

Learn once, use everywhere! üöÄ

Q: Many modern developers rely on libraries and frameworks (e.g., React, Laravel). Do you see this as a good thing?

A: I think it‚Äôs a positive evolution (though I could be wrong).

Frameworks abstract things developers don‚Äôt need to worry about, allowing them to focus on business logic.
For example, React abstracts DOM updates with its Virtual DOM, making it far better than manually updating the DOM with JavaScript or jQuery.

Q: What do you do when you‚Äôre not coding?

A:

  • Trekking in the Himalayas üèîÔ∏è (most of my vacations this year were for that).
  • Hiking üö∂
  • Drawing üé®

Q: Is your off-work routine completely separate from your work, or do you get ‚Äúaha‚Äù moments?

A: I don‚Äôt have a fixed routine, but I enjoy the things I do in my breaks.
Sometimes, I work on an interesting side project (involving code), and that feels like a good break, too.
So it‚Äôs a mix and match.

Q: Developers are often stereotyped as geeks, but the best programmers often have creative/artistic sides. Do you agree?

A: Absolutely! I see code as art.

I recently started reading other people‚Äôs code, and it‚Äôs beautiful.
Creativity isn‚Äôt just about UI or aesthetics‚Äîit‚Äôs also about how elegantly the code is written.

Q: Your best piece of programming advice?

A:
üí° ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not rocket science. Someone else wrote it, so if you spend time on it, you‚Äôll understand. Patience!‚Äù

üôè Thanks a lot, Aravind, for answering our questions! We can‚Äôt wait to see your next contributions to Bismuth! üöÄ

About Aravind

  • Software developer specializing in JavaScript.
  • Contributed to Bismuth‚Äôs client-side voting helper.
  • Currently working on a modern client-side web wallet for Bismuth.

üì¢ Connect with Aravind

  • Twitter: @aravindballa
  • Website & Blog: aravindballa.com/writings
